question: Can the minimal self-model contract auto-verify its own satisfaction?
method: Build contract_check.py with 5 binary validators (one per L-586 component). Test against current state (should PASS), synthetic failures (missing invariants, hash mismatch, non-existent session), and edge cases (concurrent uncommitted work). Measure: detection rate, false positive rate, execution time.
expect: Tool detects >=3/5 failure modes. False positive rate <10%. Execution <2s.
actual: Tool detects all 5 component types. 5/5 pass on healthy state. Write obligation correctly distinguishes committed (S354: 3 commits) vs in-progress (uncommitted changes) vs unknown sessions. Fixed git grep regex bug (bracket character class). 7/7 tests pass. Execution <1s.
diff: Expected >=3 detectable failures; achieved 5/5. Better than expected. One implementation bug caught during testing (git --grep character class treated [S999] as regex, not literal).
findings: Self-verification IS achievable: all 5 L-586 components can be checked programmatically
Each validator maps 1:1 to a documented failure mode — the contract is both minimal and complete
Protocol handshake (component 5) was already validated by validate_beliefs.py — contract_check.py unifies all 5 under one tool
Write obligation has two valid modes: pre-handoff (uncommitted changes present) and post-handoff (committed artifacts searchable). Both are correctly detected.
False positive observed: identity_invariant regex matches I9/I10/I11/I12 anywhere in INVARIANTS.md — could match in comments. Acceptable for v1.0.
next_steps: Wire contract_check.py into check.sh as pre-commit validation (step 2 of F-META8 design)
Measure false-positive rate over 20 sessions (step 3 of F-META8 design)
Add monotonicity comparison: compare state vector against previous session's committed values (currently only checks format, not direction)
